isis.stitle: TSI 96-12-30 - Cold Ambient Protection (CAP) System For Warm-Up and Maintaining Engine Heat Under Cold Ambient Conditions For International® T 444E, DT 466E and 530E Engines

subjectgroup.subject: Cold Ambient Protection (CAP) System For Warm-Up and Maintaining Engine Heat Under Cold Ambient Conditions For International® T 444E, DT 466E and 530E Engines

svcproc.title: DESCRIPTION
svcproc.para: The Cold Ambient Protection ( CAP) has been added to the electronic engine control system to aid engine warm-up and to maintain engine temperature during extended idle periods of engine operation. This change can reduce valve train damage due to valve sticking in cold weather. The following description covers the function of CAP:

item.para: Introduction was effective for DT 466E and 530E engines in November, 1996 and will be effective January, 1997 for T 444E engines.

The CAP feature slowly ramps up engine idle speed, after 5 minutes of idle time, to a preset maximum rpm when intake air temperature is below 0°C, 32°F and coolant temperature is below 65°C, 149°F (DT 466E/530E) and 70°C, 158°F (T 444E). The engine idle speed returns immediately to low idle when any of the conditions described below are present:
Engine load is greater than 25%
Brake pedal is applied or brake switch fault is detected
Clutch pedal is depressed
Shift selector is moved from neutral to forward or reverse range (automatic transmission); See Item #7 for Allison MD operation
PTO switch, also used for electronic hand throttle, is "On"
Accelerator pedal is depressed or accelerator pedal sensor fault is detected
The idle shutdown feature is enabled
Engine Coolant Temperature (ECT) sensor fault is detected
Intake Air Temperature (ambient temperature) sensor fault is detected

CAP strategies and calibration were developed to meet the specific needs of the DT 466E/530E and T 444E engines independently. Because of this, the table below shows event timing and parameter settings for each engine family.
See Event Timing and Parameter Settings Table.
The following is an example of CAP operation at -17.8°C, zero°F for unit with T 444E and manual transmission:

Engine is started cold and allowed to warm up with the conditions, described in Paragraph #2, in enable mode. After 5 minutes at low idle the CAP feature will slowly increase the engine speed to 1200 rpm. The coolant temperature will increase to 80°C, 176°F at which time the engine speed will slowly drop. When the coolant temp. drops to 70°C,158°F the engine speed will increase again until coolant temperature reaches 80°C, 176°F. This cycle will continue until any one or any combination of conditions listed in Paragraph #2 occurs; i. e. clutch pedal is depressed, PTO engaged, etc.

CAP operation with DT 466E/530E electronic engines is similar except for engine rpm, and temperature differences shown in the table above. Again, this is because of thermostat settings and engine warm up characteristic differences between DT 466E/530E and T 444E.

The lower CAP rpm limit for automatic transmissions, compared to manual transmissions, minimizes the harsh engagement should the operator place the shift lever in gear without first applying the service brakes to lower the idle speed to 700 rpm.

Vehicles equipped with Allison MD transmissions have an electronic lock out which prevents engagement of any forward or reverse range from neutral if the engine is at or above 900 rpm. When CAP is enabled it is possible for an operator to shift from neutral to fwd or reverse while engine speed is above 900 rpm. The transmission won't shift into selected range until two conditions are met:
Engine speed must be lowered by depressing brake pedal, accelerator pedal or engagement of any parameter listed in Paragraph #2.
Once engine speed is lowered, operator must select neutral then re-select desired range.
